Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project aims to develop a low cost yet durable ice-release coating to mitigate icing-related problems encountered by air transportation, power transmission, wind energy and commercial refrigeration industries. In Phase I the first laboratory test for ice adhesion using a commercial instrument led to rapid screening of ice release coating candidates. A new theory for rigid adherent removal in shear from hybrid elastomers led to a study of ice adhesion, that is, ice as a rigid adherent. Guided by the new model and practical experience gained from laboratory tests, a new coating system was identified from which ice could be removed easily and with low force. Feasibility was demonstrated for being able to produce a durable, low cost, ice-release coating with commercially available engineering materials. This was a major success that achieved the main objective of Phase I R&D. In Phase II, the main technical objectives are to decrease peak removal force and retain low cost components and easy processing.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project include generation of low cost, durable ice-release coatings and related products. These new materials will greatly reduce icing problems and enhance the safety of operations in the aerospace, energy, and refrigeration industries. More specifically, coatings developed in this project will be used as an alternative to the following: environmentally problematic de-icing fluids, energy inefficient electrical heating, and high cost but poor mechanically durable deicing coatings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ice related problems are experienced in many industrial sectors including power transmission, telecommunication, wind energy, transportation, commercial fishing and aerospace. Icing causes compromised power transmission, safety issues, and disrupted operations. For locallized ice accumulation such as aboard fishing vessels, labor intensive mechanical methods are employed for ice removal. For larger scale operations such as aircraft de-icing, products are commercially available such as environmentally problematic de-icing fluids, high cost ice release coatings with mediocre performance and poor mechanical toughness as well as energy inefficient electrical heating. For telecommunication and electric utilities, proactive methods are usually not employed. Instead, aftermath repairing is the current state-of-art. For wind turbines in the wind energy industry, using a deicing system (bench mark products all use electrical heating) or shutting down wind turbines are the usual way of protecting the turbines, equipment and the structure. Because of the energy consumption and environmental issues related to the active deice methods, there is a need for passive methods like coatings that would prevent ice formation or make ice removal easy.  

The conventional wisdom about preventing ice formation is that if water does not stick to the surface, ice should not. So there are a lot of research and development work based on the concept of superhydrophobicity, which allow water drops to form beads and roll off the surface or minimize the actual contact area of water drops and the surface. It has been proven not working in real life situations. The reasons that the superhydrophobic surfaces failed to achieve the ice protection are:

i. water in its liquid form (WATER) and water in its solid form (ICE) are two different things,

ii. the underlying assumption is that ice removal is a pure surface phenomenon,

iii. most superhydrophobic materials are often reliant upon often fragile micro-structured surfaces to achieve their intended effects,

iv. microstructured surfaces may behave like adhesion enforcement for icing conditions like frost, and

v. most real-life icing situations does not give the time for the superhydrophobic surfaces to take effect. For example when supercooled rain drops impact a cold surface at high speed, ice forms instantly and does not allow extended time for the water to form beads and roll off the surface. 

Base on a NSF funded study at Virginia Commonwealth Univeristy, a fundamentally different ice-removal model was established with considerations from multiple factors that contribute to ice-adhesion. It is important to note that VCU findings in soft surface science and engineering, which has been licensed to PEG LLC, depart from conventional thinking that focuses on water repellant superhydrophobic / low surface energy surfaces. Rather, fundamental studies provided the knowledge basis for the development of a novel coating system that takes into account multiple contributions: (1) nanosurface work of adhesion, controlled by surface energy, (2) mesosurface (~1000 nm) that controls frontier mechanical properties, and (3) bulk, that defines coating thickness and overall mechanical properties. Transitioning these new findings to commercial applications, PEG LLC has developed a low-cost easy-release coating with engineering materials. This easily tailored coating also features good toughness and durability. 

The mechanical strength not only helped the coating to survive the ice removal process, but also provided enough toughness and durability for real world applications such as wind turbine blade coatings. For wind turbine blades and airplanes, the high relative speed between the surface and rain drops or particle would cause severe erosion problems. The coating that has to be the top layer of the coating to perform the function of releasing ice would also be the first layer of materials that get eroded away. Erosion resistance was not a scope of work for this project, but a third party testing showed that the ice release coatings with mesosurface has very good erosion resistance.
